Review Title: Worst job and manager I've had
Pros: 100% Remote, "Flexible" hours, Free Udemy
Cons:
Team has gone from more than 12 people to less than 4 but leadership sets OKRs at 200% of previous targets so 1 person currently has the job scope of 3 - 4 people. The pressure is all on you to figure out how to hit those targets and execute without documentation, but you only get pointed out for when you missed out something, not when you keep everything smoothly. They will say it's because of the "hard-core" culture — sounds like a great word to force everyone to work to their bone eh?


Manager pulls you into meetings 1 minute before that are not scheduled in the calendar and meetings are scheduled without respect for your PTO/bank holidays. You will find hardly any need to foster any relationship with coworkers, because why would you when they leave within a couple of months.

I had left a good job and a good manager in a job where I exceeded expectations to come here, and almost everyday I feel regretful.

Cons:
- No work-life balance
- More than 12 hours work each day

Review Title: Another number in the pool of replaceable cogs.
Pros: Many coworkers are awesome and during bull markets there are lots of benefits.
Cons: Disconnection between employee and leadership. Too many steps in the corporate ladder. Decision-making is fogged by people who do not have your best interest at heart, causing nonsensical targets and metrics. They pay you in accordance to your place of residence, very big gaps between people in the same position, living in 1st vs. 3rd world countries.

Pros: Compensation is decent. Some good people work at the company. Exciting industry to be a part of
Cons: Company is super dodgy - as can be seen from their current global regulatory issues. They have also paid off people in certain markets to make their criminal issues go away. They have built inferior internal tools to replace Microsoft Office and Google Suites in order to avoid easy access for US authorities to their information. They suffer from massive hubris, believing they have reinvented the corporation in just 5 years. they refuse to do a forecast for example - something that would have allowed them to spot early on that they were over-hiring, rather than then letting go of 1,500 people they had pulled out of good jobs but could not afford CZ recites his latest management book readings as though they are gospel, but has no idea how to actually manage people, and he and his co-founders maintain a tight inner circle that controls all decisions - even those they are spectacularly unqualified to make. The culture is toxic, most conversations are extremely transactional - everyone works remote, no one switches on their cameras, some people use aliases, and no one bothers with relationship building. Why would you? The turnover is astonishingly high - people leave without any announcement being made and suddenly you have to find someone else to turn to for information. Again, because they are so dodgy, they don’t have proper org charts which makes it a nightmare internally trying to find someone to help you with your work Avoid, avoid, avoid….

Working from home is also a pro, there's flexibility so you can manage your time independently.
Cons: Lack of organizational structure and leadership are still soft.

Review Title: Horrible work-life balance, penalised and judged if you don't work 12h+
Pros: - Unfortunately, there aren't any
Cons:
- 40% Lower wages than the avg. of tech/fintech/crypto industries
- Horrible CEO, making the team compete with each other constantly by adding internal features to rate anyone in the company anonymously with "good" or "bad"
- Horrible HR set up, they force people to rate people very high up or down, no middle ground, those that are on the down level, will be fired right away
- Creating constant fear of being fired. They will point fingers if you make a small mistake or they just don't like what you say, if you take holidays and if you work less than 12h+/day. Saying no to night calls leads to a laid off.
- Aggressive and toxic culture. People will go for you and put everyone against you until they get your job and you are fired
- Managers will reach out to you on weekends, nights, all time long, won't respect your holidays nor your family/parental leave

Review Title: Toxic culture - enter as your own risk.
Pros: Web3 company. Pay is ok to average. Market leader.
Cons:
- Management is not interested in your development, they want you to work as many hours as possible and then burn out. Inhuman.
- You are managed by numbers, you are not a person to them
- Firing is quick and common, and top performers are only as good as their last quarter.
- Employees are asked to rate each other, which creates infighting, not a positive team dynamic.
- the culture of the company is non-existent. Mostly just long hours and bullying to get things done. Toxic culture.
- Long-term incentives is not aligned with the ask from employees.

Review Title: It’s not smoke and mirrors, but it isn’t much better
Pros:
- If you get in before 2020/2021 
- If you know senior management directly
- If you are used to mainland Chinese management style 
- If you are willing to work the moments you wake up to the moments you sleep
-  If you are lucky and placed in special projects
-  If you don’t mind your benefits getting cut quarter after quarter
Cons: The only good part is we do hire some good and talented people. But fully remote work is never going to work for a company with 7K employees. With the crazy high turnovers and non-stop “rightsizing” (yes Managment actually dare to rephrase it like this in front of everyone), I won’t be surprise if the quality of the company and its people drops like a cliff in the next 24 months.

Review Title: Awesome execution energy but horrible culture. Avoid unless salary is the only consideration.
Pros: 1. Huge Vision. Clear internal intent to change the world 2. Very clear priorities from top. No time wasting running random optimisations 3. You wil probably out execute your peers given the clear direction and super hard working team. 4. Top 10 percentile salary for leadership salary. Remote if that is your thing
Cons: 1. The amount of work is insane. If you are on one of the important team expect to be working 60-70 hours a week 2. Horrible culture - Never expect anyone to ever pat your back. Expect to be thrown under the bus by your trusted colleagues. Most employees are scared of getting fired all the time. 3. Extremely top down - CZ knows(/thinks he knows) what needs to be done and how it must be done. He doesnt care what you think should be done. He will tell you what to do and you execute(goes ever for CXOs). Expect your bosses even upto C suite to be involved in minute details of your work at a daily basis. 4. No comrade feeling - Noone ever turns on their camera during meetings. Company built with efficiency as a cornerstone to be point that there is no relationship Last, the secrecy around everything you do and how you do things is insane. Dont expect Binance to even give you an experience letter when you leave.

Review Title: Great and rewarding place to accumulate knowledge, but not much else
Unreasonable expectations, lack of transparency, frequent firing
Pros: Binance is a well-known crypto company
Cons: Terrible hours, expect to work 24/7 - Most of the leadership is based in the Middle East or APAC. If you live outside of those time zones, you will be regularly expected to attend calls before 7am and after 10pm North America time. Highly centralized and political - All decisions roll up to the leadership team. Even small decisions need to be looked at by CZ. Decisions take forever and the leadership team is always the gatekeeper of approvals, yet they expect you to reach absurdly high KPIs. Unreasonable expectations - They expect you to regularly work until 3am and attend meetings at ~6am, and set KPIs that are 2-5 times more than what a normal company would set. They motivate employees through fear of getting fired since no one can hit these KPIs. Chinese-centric - If you do not speak business Chinese, you will not make it far in this company. Most of the leadership is Chinese native, and not English native. If you cannot present your ideas in Chinese, it may fall on deaf ears. There is a "PMO" or bilingual secretary (usually a senior IC-level junior person) assigned to each member of leadership. These PMOs are constantly trying to gatekeep and elevate themselves, even if it means throwing team members under the bus. Lack of integrity - during the mass 2023 US employee layoff, there were cases of actively reducing severance packages initially promised.

Review Title: no life-work balance, bad management team
Pros: work remotely, good pay, good teammates
Cons: they hired many employees these 2 years, and now need to let some people go. Some senior management teams won't consider the employees' performance, they just consider which employees have a good relationship with them and keep them, especially the product team.

Pros: Awesome place to work, exciting opportunities.
Cons: Crypto market fluctuates too much and does affect the company.

Cons: -so many secrets, recommended us to not put on LinkedIn publicly (which is still fine i guess... but not common for other big company) -workload on many things! sometime can get add more product to cover and we cover multiple products at the same time -after the mass layoff in mid 2023, 1 person can cover multiple regions.. basically 4-5 people's job in 1 person.... with no pay raise :( -able to lay off you JUST like that, my case was get called at afternoon, and have no access to everything by EOD (is it normal?)

Review Title: The company doesn’t care about you
Pros: Work remote, salary is good (if you’re European), if not, just okay.
Cons: If you’re no in Europe, salary will be lot lower. Management doesn’t care about you at all, in Binance you are 100% replaceable, just a number. If you’re not Chinese, you can’t even try to reach higher places, the leaders don’t care about you, and it’s pretty clear. Massive lay-off are happening since January, with the excuses of bottoming out. They don’t follow any labor laws and don’t seems to care about it, you will be constantly exposed a high pressure that will lead to a burn out, soon or later. Lots os people work in a wrong way to get more points on kpi, they don’t care about rules. Mostly those remain, and the ones who try to act right are fired. You can’t raise your voice against the upper management, I’ve saw several times where workers were basically called dumb for reporting something to the management, beside that, if you do this, the countdown for you to be fired is on. Things only change when CZ received a tweet and this goes viral.

They do not portrait the values they show so greatly in their core values website and all, only pretty paper empty words. Overall, stay away from this company. I am eagerly waiting for the day I finally get a new job.

Review Title: Remote CS at Binance is not bad
Pros: -Good perks such as: global insurance up to 80k$ in a year, lot's of gifts, for anniversary they gave merch, iPad, Apple watch. Fun team. -Overall easy work, flexible, can work from anyhere in the world as long as you got Wi-Fi. -They provide the latest top notch macbook pro -Yearly bonus is not bad, depending on personal performance it can be a solid amount
Cons: -Not competitive salary, almost every other exchange pays 50% more, even the small ones -Salary is passport and ethnicity based. If you are from LATAM or SEA you will get around 1000$, while the EU. AU or NA colleagues from the same team that do the exact same job will get at least double and sometimes triple of that from the beginning and they get higher annual increment on top. -Very small salary increment every year - No job security during bear market, they hired new people like crazy during bull run and then just started firing them by hundreds and thousands during the bear market, literally just after 6 months from hiring craze. Why hire so much people at the first place if can't survive bear market -Thin chance to get promoted, they prefer to promote the ethnical Chinese more than the others

Pros: work remotely and flexible hours(but overtime)
Cons: Toxic managment, no promotion, cut deadlines, work overtime

Pros: Able to work on various data projects
Cons: Not stable as the market goes up and down

Pros:
Discretionary yearly bonus

WFA 3 months yearly
Cons: Working outside of shift hours

Pros: Fully WFH, colleagues are helpful, everyone has a same goal. Just to try their best to earn their keep
Cons: Lots of demands from upper management, no such thing as work life balance, weekends and PH also need to work. Needed to work 3 weekends out of 4 in a month.

Pros:
Kind teammates
Good hours
Exciting projects
Cons: Low salary for a junior

Pros: There are people in there who are genuinely putting in the effort towards the improvement of the company. When the market was thriving, they went above and beyond to compensate employees with good bonuses and exceptional benefits. Top company of the industry. Good opportunity to experience collaborating with people from countries all over the map. You may be lucky to work with great team members. I've heard stories of many people like this, however, being such a broad, mostly remote company, every member tells a different story of their experience in Binance. In my time here, I'd say I have heard a 70/30 ratio in negative/positive stories including the present year. Last year It would have been a more even number.
Cons: If the idea of the display of true character in the face of adversity is true, I do not think Binance did a good job when adversity has hit it, and it shows in its growing negative feedback as it does in the current inner atmosphere. Ruling by fear, causing a point-the-finger and cover-my-ass-first culture over addressing problems with problem solving drive as its priority, which is hard to avoid when no one wants to look stupid in group communications. Very low display of accountability at the organizational level. They strongly encourage feedback, yet all I see when angry people submit feedback to Binance, is that their response is basically to 'apologize' for your personal feelings (which anyone with any sense understands it's a diplomatic copout) then proceed to send you a link to an article where they explain why Binance is basically not wrong, it's just complicated and you were not a cultural fit. Might as well not reply, I cannot imagine anyone reads those replies and empathizes with the company's side.

Pros: - Good compensation package - Annual bonus (despite decreasing every year) - Exposure to the crypto industry
Cons: Company is far too disorganized and toxic. Most employees are Chinese and company culture revolves 100% around them. If you don’t speak Chinese, your chances to grow in this place are minimal. - Very little training to get you up to speed. It’s up to you to figure things out and you’ll be called out if mistakes are made. - Communication is quite poor across teams especially with Chinese speaking employees who are quite indirect in their communication. Most employees speak English very poorly so communication is greatly impacted as a result. - Morale at the company feels low, and micromanagement is fierce to the point your manager is constantly breathing down your neck. - Lack of transparency: a lot happens behind your back and some of these things have an impact on your work. - Performance is based on unrealistic KPIs: you are judged by quantity delivered over quality in your work. - Dog-eat-dog culture: people will do anything to get credit. - WLB could be better: your life is just work, and you’ll get burned out quite easily. - Poor code and system design leading to many problems and inconsistencies that impact customers directly.

Review Title: Rigid and Hierarchical, Very hard if you are not Chinese speaking
Pros: Flexible schedule, work from home, good pay, most successful and forefront crypto exchange. Performance is highly valued and reviewed regularly and systematically.
Cons: - Severe lack of transparency. You only know what your team is doing, and you don't know what other teams are out there and how they relate to yours. - Everything is confidential so you cannot view code you depend on like of CICD pipelines for example - Very stressful and high workload, often expected to work weekends - No testing culture - No code review culture, so a lot of low quality, untested code is committed - Technology is rigid and outdated, and because of the way the versioning of components is designed, everything has to move together which is very slow - The vast majority of the tech team is Chinese, with most having very bad english, so if you don't speak it, a lot of communication is done behind your back, and a even if they want to, most colleagues do not feel comfortable communicating with you in english - The sphere of tools and libraries are not familiar to non Chinese - Blame culture - Very hierarchical, leads only care about achieving their goals, and not the benefit of the wider team.

Pros: Good benefit and flexible schedule.
Cons: Not an open minded company, not in the team I worked for. Managers and colleagues were too emotional and could not distinguish between work and personal life.

Pros: Decent pay and benefits. Full remote working.
Cons: Where to begin? Incompetent and entitled leadership team - it gets worse the further up the ladder you go. Many of the decision makers (or indecision makers?) are either literally old friends of the CEO or mediocre hangers on who have nodded their up the food chain. 24/7, unrelenting chasing and bickering on the internal comms platform (usually as a side effect to comically inefficient processes with little quality work actually being done) - a complete disregard for the human beings on the other end. A backstabbing and blame culture that I’ve never seen anything close to before. I’ve witnessed someone fabricate a situation in order get one of their team members fired - and it worked (my concerns over this were then laughed off and ignored by HR). Completely opaque organisation - for a company claiming to be focused on the ‘freedom of money’ they sure do have a lot to hide, even from their own employees. Mainland China style work culture (though saying that is probably unfair to other Chinese companies) 9-9-6 would be an improvement for the work life balance of many at Binance. A company that claims to be a flat and dynamic organisation but is deeply hierarchical - good luck challenging or questioning any of the aforementioned ‘leaders’ - these are Binancian royalty who need not take advice from us plebeians. Middle managers who dare attempt to do so get put through the shredder immediately. .

Cons: Please come in with your eyes wide open. This place lacks professional and ethical standards overtly Chinese-working style and bad role modelling and tone set at the founder levels. i.e. Toxic culture. No psychological safety and no diversity, Unhealthy collusion, Nepotism have been observed.

Pros: Remote working and a great pay package are a dream when the market is doing well...or so you think...
Cons: The expectation is that you work almost 24/7 and they're tracking your use of the laptop. You will be punished for being efficient at your job and the so-called freedom is only a perception as finishing your work efficiently makes management think you are skiving. When e-learning is not completed. HR threatens to withhold your pay. Having a high compensation from the company is the very reason you may lose your job when management suddenly decides to cut costs. HR and management also intend to find several excuses to try and fire individuals without severance and insidiously get your managers to schedule one-on-one calls but will unpleasantly bait-and-switch you with HR in a call to let you know you have been made redundant. Despite what the CEO says about letting people go on twitter, the truth is far from it. The company likes to operate in ambiguity and has questionable practices. Management makes decisions on whims and not based on logic and there are many single points of failure with no business resiliency. It's a sinking ship. Best beware.

Review Title: good company but need to clean up a bit

Cons: the company is paying attention on bottom out, but meanwhile wasting many talents without knowledge. I have heard of many bully managers, who did not like the employee and prevented them to do more good. I cannot say I am %100 in the same situation but I had similar situation where my supervisor never appreciated the hard work I have done (verbally yes but I have never saw it on performance rating). I will refer this person as 'them' Them, underestimated my work during the meets in front of my other colleagues, has given me really bad feedback which does not rely on any fact. The company take feedback system into seriously but I do not believe in anonymity so unfortunately to keep my job I stayed silent.

Review Title: culture that I find it hard to recognize anymore
Pros: Was once a awesome place to find people who had the same passion to work towards the same goals
Cons: Dramatic change in business lines, massive layoffs going on and on, replacing full time members with contractors or even interns, or simply just expect the rest of the members to carry a crazy workload left by their peers.
